MainClaim.text: "Malabou's book offers a critique of neuronal ideology and argues that brain plasticity can be a model for a conception of the production of the new

Untitled1.text: "The question of freedom has been inverted since Kant

Untitled2.text: "Neuroscience has a unique position as a human science that claims to be grounded in the hard sciences and provides a scientific explanation of human thought and behavior

Untitled3.text: "Malabou's analysis of plasticity in the brain shows how it operates at every level of the brain

Untitled4.text: "The discovery of the plasticity of the brain reflects the structure of capitalism and points the way for a conception of the production of the new."

Untitled6.text: "Malabou argues that the plasticity of the brain can move in one of two directions: either it can constitute the biological justification of a type of economic

Untitled7.text: "Malabou proposes a kind of'meta-neurobiology' that views the transition from the neuronal to the mental as a dialectical process

Untitled8.text: "Malabou's ultimate position seems closer to Foucault and Deleuze

Untitled9.text: "Malabou argues that we should not allow the plasticity of our brains to simply replicate the current economic demand for flexibility

Untitled10.text: "Malabou concludes by admonishing her readers to 'construct a relation with their brain as the image of a world to come'."

Untitled11.text: Malabou calls for an 'awakening of a consciousness of the brain

Untitled12.text: "Malabou's book offers a critique of neuronal ideology and argues that brain plasticity can be a model for a conception of the production of the new

Untitled13.text: "The only real view of progress opened by the neurosciences is that of an improvement in the 'quality of life' through a better treatment of illness

Untitled14.text: "Malabou argues that the fascinating discoveries of the neurosciences are incapable of unleashing possibilities
